div.head:
Embleme 20. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Nature teacheth nature how to subdue fire.
Epigramme 20.
div.lg:
Fire that insulting dragon is praepard
To scorch the virgins beauty Sans regard:
degree blackDistresed for help shee spyes a man of warre
Equippd all cap a pe, as such men are,
who, sheilding her from harme, assaults the flames,
And by this praesident her fear reclaimes.

div.head: Discourse 20.
div.ab:
The common token and symboll, by which the Philosophers know one another,
is, that nature is guided, taught, governed, subdued and overcome by nature, as
a young Scholar by a Mistresse, a waiting mayd by her Lady, a subject by a
Queen, yea a daughter by the mother, and kinswoman by kinswoman: how
true it is, appears by dayly experience, in the education of youth amongst
men, and other actions, as literary discipline or institution, government, and
the like. Pliny writes of the Nightingalls, that one teacheth, attends, observes,
imitates, overcomes another in singing, or being overcome greives, and that
sometimes being outdone and vanquished in the conflict, the throat being broken,
it perisheth, and in the midle of singing falls downe dead: Wee see allso how
all sorts of birds doe begin to accustome and instruct their young being yet
unfeathered and tender for flying, that not onely nature, but allso art or
use hath begotten in them the habit of flying, though nature alone gave
power and organs to exercise that action, without which neither institution
or art can find foundation or place: soe colts are taught to runne by the
mare, whelps to barke by the bitch, and young foxes to craft by the
dam, nor is there any animated and sensitive nature or species of na
ture found, which guides, instructs, and governs not another nature, as its
minor, or suffers itselfe to be overcome by another, as a parent: Wee doe
not perceive such discipline in vegetables, yet notwithstanding the use is
observed in them, and that mens hands are of much efficacy: for whilst
corne is in the blade, it may be cleansed from incommodious thistles and
tares, whilst a tree is yet a twig it may be bent, and made to grow as
you please: Soe in metalls and Philosophicall subjects one nature keeps,
praeserves, and defends another nature in fire, as is knowne to founders and
testers, but especially to the masters of naturall things: Iron is very helpfull
and as a midwife to Silver and gold being yet very tender and Spirituall,
as they call it, mixd in its mynes with Cadmia, Arsenicke, or Antimony
the cheife, if it be cast into mynes to be burnd in a fire of furnaces:
after the same manner iron itselfe, if it be intended to be changed into
Steele, is saved from burning by white stones found at the Sea Shoares;
Some doe cast the powders of crystall glasse, or the gall of glasse upon
metallicke powders which are to be dissolved, that they may not pe
rish by over much fire: Instead of this gall of glasse the Philosophers
doe use their Eudica, which Morienus sas is allso the gall of glasse,
and to be had in glasse vessells: for the heat of fire consumes the body
with hasty burning: but Eudica applyed will free bodyes changed into
earth from any burning: For bodyes, when now they doe not retaine
their soules, are soon burned: Eudica (the faex of glasse) is indeed very
agreable to all bodyes, for it vivifyes and praepares them, and defends
them from all burning: These are the sayings of Morienus the Roman:
This therefore is the nature, which teacheth another nature to resist
fire, and be enured to it, which is the Mistresse instructing the
Discourse 20.
young Schollar, and if you consider well, which is the Queen governing
the subject, and which is the daughter nobilitating and dignifying the mother;
This is that red servant, which is joynd in matrimony with his odoriferous
mother, and of her begets a progeny farre more noble than the parents
thereof: This is Pyrrhus the Sonne of Achilles, and the young man with
red haire, golden vestment, blacke eyes, white feet: This is the knight
with a collar or chaine armed with sword and buckler against the Dra
gon, to rescue out of his jawes the pure and unviolated virgin Albifica,
sirnamed Beja, or Blanca: This is the monster=killing Hercules, who
delivered from the monster Hesione the daughter of Laomedon being
exposed to a terible and cruell Whale: This is that Perseus, who de
fended (released, and marryed) Andromeda, the daughter of Cassiope
and Cepheus King of Aethiopia, from the Sea monster, Shewing the
head of Medusa: This is hee that may be compared with those ancient Ro
mans the praeservers and refiners of the people, Marcus Curtius, Lucius Scae
vola, Horatius Cocles, Manlius Capitolinus, and the like, to rescue the
Citty, as it were the mother, from dangers: For this is the way and forme
of nature tending to the perfection of any worke, to bring one thing out
of another, a thing more perfect out of a thing imperfect, and reduce
power into action, but not perfect all things in a moment, but one thing
after another: Nor this alone, but shee constitutes allso her deputy in the
first place, to which Shee leaves the power of life and death, that is, of
forming other things, as for example, in the generation of man Shee
useth a long processe, as of tenne moneths, where first attending to the
opinion of Aristotle, Shee fabricates the heart, as the vicar deputy, or
principall bowell, and then the heart delineates, formes, and perfects
the other parts necessary to nutrition, the life, senses, and generative
power, and comunicates to them life and vivificke spirits by Systole
and diastole, or dilatation and compression of the arteryes, soe long
as it is not impeded by diseases and violence: And thus one nature
teacheth another, which you must observe and follow for an example
of the Philosophicall worke, as a thing most clear and evident
